title: First Deosai Plains Festival promoting “soft” tourism in Pakistan
text:
First Deosai Plains Festival promoting “soft” tourism in Pakistan   
Aug 21, 2015 eTN   
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan - The first Deosai Plains Festival will start on August 28 to promote tourism in Gilgit-Baltistan in Pakistan. 
“The 3-day colorful cultural festival at Deosai plains will be organized by the government of Gilgit-Baltistan from August 28 to boost tourism industry as well as promote [a] soft image of the country,” said Muhammad Jehanzaib, the Secretary Information of Gilgit-Baltistan, while addressing a press briefing on Thursday. 
He further said the festival was being organized for the first time in history to attract tourists at the world’s second highest altitude plateau – the Deosai Plains - to boost the tourism potential encompassing multi-cultural and multi-ethnic aspects of the area. 
The festival will serve visitors to explore all kind of attractions, both for domestic and foreign tourists, at the plains including water sports, musical nights, cultural performances, horse riding, a jeep rally, and many other activities. 
The musical night at the plains includes the performance of singers from the mainstream and local area while the rich festivities of the event will be a reflection of the mountainous communities with rich traditions. 
The “King of Games and Game of Kings” – polo - will be the hallmark of the event, which usually attracts a huge number of spectators from all over the world, Jehanzaib said. 
The overall aim of the festival is to promote ecotourism, adventure tourism, and culture tourism coupled with mountain trekking expeditions both at the national and international level, while the organizers will also take care of the environmental protection in the area, the Secretary Information GB said. 
The government of GB is funding the festival, while the security of the tourists will also be ensured by the organizers as a record number of tourists visited GB this year, he added. 
The former Consultant to the Ministry of Tourism in the government of Pakistan and President of The Region Initiative (TRI), Agha Iqrar Haroon, while appreciating the decision of holding the festival said that government has given a very little time to promote this event internationally, and the event should have been announced at least six months earlier. He added that it looked like the event was planned in haste and would not get the desired result to promote a soft image of the country, as this event has not been sold in packages to the public, as well as private tour operators. He demanded to the ministry that the next festival should be announced next year well before its actual date. Source: Dispatch News Desk
